results.title: Waterfront safety
results.creator_credit: Western Australian Government Film Unit and Western Australia. Dept. of Labour
results.brief_description:
This 1966 film takes place on the wharfs and ships at Fremantle Harbour, demonstrating safe working methods for waterside workers. It shows the correct handling of various types of cargo, including logs, grain and phosphate mined from Nauru. It emphasises the use of protective clothing and equipment. The film also shows the prevention and control of fires, including fire fighting ships.

Produced by the Western Australian Government Film Unit and presented by the Western Australian Department of Labour with Accident Prevention Organisation (Shipping).

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Reaching for the stars
results.creator_credit: Loch Townsend, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian news and Information Bureau
results.brief_description: Shows Australian research in astronomy. Visits the observatory at Mount Stromolo, which houses big telescopes, cameras to map the skies, and the National Time Service. Goes on to show research on radio astronomy at the Radiophysics Laboratory (CSIRO), Sydney, and using Mills cross of stationary aerials and other devices. Pictures the windmill aerials at Dapto, used for tracking the sun

results.title: The Rail way
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Don Murray, Department of Transport and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A look at railways in Australia from Alice Springs to Kalgoorlie and Normanton. Shows trains serving the mining fields in central Queensland and the suburban trains of the big cities. Discusses problems brought about by different gauges throughout the country, and looks at the economic future of railways. Commentator Patsy Adam-Smith.

results.title: Rail town
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson, Joan Long and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Dramatises the activities and life of the people of Port Augusta, South Australia, with emphasis on the significance of this city as a railhead linking the Eastern States with the West and the Northern Territory.

results.title: A Race of horses
results.creator_credit: Kit Denton, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows without commentary the breeding and training of racehorses in Australia. Includes scenes of foaling, breaking-in and handling the young horses, and an actual race sequence. Photographed by renown cameraman Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kit Denton, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: RAAF Record. Newsreel No. 07
results.creator_credit: Stanley Brogden and Australia. Royal Australian Air Force. Directorate of Public Relations
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine newsreel includes the following: 1. The RAAF flight in the Antarctic use Canadian “Beaver” aircraft. 2. RAAF personnel are trained by firemen in Melbourne. 3. The Lockheed Hercules transport. 4. The “Jindivik” pilotless aircraft, designed and built in Australia, shown in flight at Woomera range.

results.title: RAAF heritage
results.creator_credit: Stanley Dalby, Roland Beckett and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The history of the Royal Australian Air Force and the original Australian Flying Corps, showing action in World Wars I and II, Korea, Malaya and Vietnam.

results.title: The Queen Returns
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Stanley Hawes and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The visit of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth and His Royal Highness Prince Phillip to Australia. Much of the film is devoted to Canberra and its history as the Queen’s visit coincided with Canberra’s Jubilee Celebrations.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Bagnall, Stanley Hawes and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

holdings.name: MOV file H264; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: The Queen in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The Queen in Australia is a landmark in Australian history. It not only records the first visit by a reigning monarch to Australia, it was also the first colour, feature-length documentary made in this country. This historic program provides nationwide coverage of the 1954 Royal Tour by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and HRH the Duke of Edinburgh - a two-month journey that took in every facet of Australian life: garden parties at Government House, dancers at the Tivoli, racing at Randwick, tennis at Kooyong with Rosewall and Hoad, cricket with the Don, even a meeting with Papua New Guinean tribal chiefs. The young royals visited every state in the nation, and the result is a remarkable and revealing insight into our nation in the 1950s.

results.title: Queen cotton
results.creator_credit: C Beaumont, Cecil Musk and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Looks at the cotton industry in Lancashire which, in the middle of this century, supplied most of the world with cotton goods. Features cranes on the docks in Manchester unloading cotton from all over the world to supply the looms of Lancashire. Includes a fashion shows highlighting cotton fabrics used by well-known British designers. Photographed by Jimmy Rogers, music by William Alwyn and editing by C. Beaumont.
